      "karma": 3,
      "title": "Question On Codomain",
      "body": " Your friend Susan has become interested in functions \\(f\\colon\\R \\sto \\R\\) which preserve both the operation of addition and the operation of multiplication; that is, functions \\(f\\) which satisfy  \\begin{align}           f(x+y) \u0026\u003d f(x) + f(y)     \\\\ \\intertext{and}           f(xy)  \u0026\u003d f(x)f(y)    \\end{align} for all \\(x,y \\in \\R.\\)   Naturally she started her investigation by looking at some examples.    The trouble is that she was able to find only two very simple examples: \\(f(x) \u003d 0\\) for all \\(x\\) and \\(f(x) \u003d x\\) for all \\(x\\).    After expending considerable effort she was unable to find additional examples.    She now conjectures that there are no other functions satisfying \\eqref{pf_30_1} and\\eqref{pf_30_2}.   Write Susan a letter explaining why she is correct.   \u003ci\u003eHint.\u003c/i\u003e  You may choose to pursue the following line of argument.    Assume that \\(f\\) is a function (not identically zero) which satisfies \\eqref{pf_30_1} and\\eqref{pf_30_2} above.\n  (a) Show that \\(f(0) \u003d 0\\).    [In \\eqref{pf_30_1} let \\(y\u003d0\\).]\n  (b) Show that if \\(a \\ne 0\\) and \\(a \u003d ab\\), then \\(b\u003d1\\).\n  (c) Show that \\(f(1) \u003d 1\\).   [How do we know that there exists a number \\(c\\) such that \\(f(c) \\ne 0\\)?  Let \\(x\u003dc\\) and \\(y\u003d1\\) in\\eqref{pf_30_2}.]\n  (d) Show that \\(f(n) \u003d n\\) for every natural number \\(n\\).\n  (e) Show that \\(f(-n) \u003d -n\\) for every natural number \\(n\\).   [Let \\(x\u003dn\\) and \\(y\u003d-n\\) in\\eqref{pf_30_1}.   Use (d).]\n  (f) Show that \\(f(1/n) \u003d 1/n\\) for every natural number \\(n\\).   [Let \\(x\u003dn\\) and \\(y\u003d1/n\\) in\\eqref{pf_30_2}.]\n  (g) Show that \\(f(r)\u003dr\\) for every rational number \\(r\\).   [If \\(r \\ge 0\\) write \\(r \u003d m/n\\) where \\(m\\) and \\(n\\) are natural numbers; then use \\eqref{pf_30_2}, (d), and(e).   Next consider the case \\(r\u003c0\\).]\n  (h) Show that if \\(x \\ge 0\\), then \\(f(x) \\ge 0\\).   [Write \\(x\\) as \\(\\sqrt x\\sqrt x\\) and use\\eqref{pf_30_2}.]\n  (i) Show that if \\(x \\le y\\), then \\(f(x) \\le f(y)\\).   [Show that \\(f(-x) \u003d -f(x)\\) holds for all real numbers\\(x\\).    Use (h).]\n  (j) Now prove that \\(f\\) must be the identity function on\\(\\R\\).    [Argue by contradiction: Assume \\(f(x) \\ne x\\) for some number \\(x\\).   Then there are two possibilities: either \\(f(x) \u003e x\\) or \\(f(x) \u003c x\\).   Show that both of these lead to a contradiction.   Apply theorem\\ref{thm_rats_dense} to the two cases \\(f(x) \u003e x\\) and \\(f(x) \u003c x\\) to obtain the contradiction \\(f(x) \u003c f(x)\\).]",

      "body": " For the purposes of this problem you may assume that the differential equation        \\begin{equation}                  y\u0027\u0027 + y \u003d 0 \\tag{\\(\\ast\\)}        \\end{equation} has at least one nontrivial solution on the real line.   (That is, there exists at least one twice differentiable function \\(y\\), not identically zero, such that \\(y\u0027\u0027(x) + y(x) \u003d 0\\) for all \\(x \\in \\R\\).)\n  (a) Show that if \\(u\\) and \\(v\\) are solutions of \\eqref{2ode} and \\(a\\), \\(b \\in \\R\\), then \\(w \u003d au + bv\\) and \\(u\u0027\\) are also solutions of\\eqref{2ode}.\n  (b) Show that if \\(y\\) is a solution of \\eqref{2ode} then \\(y^2 + (y\u0027)^2\\) is constant.\n  (c) Show that if \\(y\\) is a nontrivial solution of \\eqref{2ode}, then either \\(y(0) \\ne 0\\) or \\(y\u0027(0) \\ne 0\\).   \u003ci\u003eHint.\u003c/i\u003e Argue by contradiction.   Show that if \\(y\\) is a solution of \\((\\ast)\\) such that both \\(y(0) \u003d 0\\) and \\(y\u0027(0) \u003d 0\\), then \\(y(x) \u003d 0\\) for all \\(x\\).\n  (d) Show that there exists a solution \\(s\\) of \\eqref{2ode} such that \\(s(0) \u003d 0\\) and \\(s\u0027(0) \u003d 1\\).   \u003ci\u003eHint.\u003c/i\u003e  Let \\(y\\) be a nontrivial solution of \\eqref{2ode}.   Look for a solution \\(s\\) of the form \\(a y + b y\u0027 \\text{ (with \\)a\\(, \\)b \\in \\R\\()}\\) satisfying the desired conditions.\n  (e) Show that if \\(y\\) is a solution of \\eqref{2ode} such that \\(y(0) \u003d a\\) and \\(y\u0027(0) \u003d b\\), then \\(y \u003d b s + a s\u0027\\).   \u003ci\u003eHint.\u003c/i\u003e  Let \\(u(x) \u003d y(x) - b s(x) - a s\u0027(x)\\) and show that \\(u\\) is a solution of \\eqref{2ode} such that \\(u(0) \u003d u\u0027(0) \u003d 0\\).   Use(c).\n  (f) Define \\(c(x) \u003d s\u0027(x)\\) for all \\(x\\).   Show that \\((s(x))^2 + (c(x))^2 \u003d 1\\) for all \\(x\\).\n  (g) Show that \\(s\\) is an odd function and that \\(c\\) is even.   \u003ci\u003eHint.\u003c/i\u003e To see that \\(s\\) is odd let \\(u(x) \u003d s(-x)\\) for all \\(x\\).       "body": " Your good friend Fred is confused again.   He is trying to find \\(\\ell \u003d \\D\\lim_{x \\sto 0^+}(1 + x)^{1/x}\\).    It is clear him that for \\(x \u003e 0\\) the quantity in parentheses, \\(1 + x\\), is always strictly greater than\\(1\\). So \\(\\ell\\) is the result of taking a number strictly greater than \\(1\\) to higher and higher powers and, therefore, \\(l \u003d \\infty\\).       "body": " Suppose that a function \\(f\\) is increasing on the interval \\((-\\infty,-5)\\) and is also increasing on the interval \\((-5,\\infty)\\).    Is it necessarily the case that \\(f\\) must be increasing on the set \\((-\\infty,-5) \\cup (-5,\\infty)\\)? Explain.",
      "allAnswers": [],
      "tags": "monotonicity and concavity, increasing, decreasing, monotone, concave up, concave down",
      "url": "/question/aa94a671-e18a-4a7b-9501-235e893bdef5",
      "source": "Exercises and Problems In Calculus (J. M. Erdman)",
      "topicUrl": "Calculus/Curve Sketching/Concavity and Inflection Points"
    },
    {
      "uuid": "374cfe92-3351-43ef-9aac-cfb4fb8a930c",
      "contentType": "question",
      "creatorUserId": "",
      "createdAt": 1437403432903,
      "anonymous": true,
      "submitted": true,
      "viewable": true,
      "karma": 3,
      "title": "Monotone Question",
      "body": " An \\df{equation of state} of a substance is an equation expressing a relationship between the pressure \\(P\\), the volume \\(V\\), and the temperature \\(T\\) of the substance.   A \\df{van der Waals gas} is a gas for which there exist positive constants \\(a\\) and \\(b\\) (depending on the particular gas) such that the following equation of state holds: \\begin{equation}  \\biggl(P + \\frac a{V^2}\\biggr)(V - b) \u003d RT.   \\tag{\\(\\ast\\)} \\end{equation} (Here \\(R\\) is a universal constant, \u003ci\u003enot\u003c/i\u003e depending on the particular gas.) For each fixed value of \\(T\\) the equation of state \\eqref{vdw} can be used to express \\(P\\) as a function of \\(V\\), say \\(P \u003d f(V)\\).   A \\df{critical temperature}, which we denote by \\(T_c\\), is a value of \\(T\\) for which the corresponding function \\(f\\) possesses a critical point which is also a point of inflection.   The \\(V\\) and \\(P\\) coordinates of this critical point are denoted by \\(V_c\\) and \\(P_c\\) and are called the \\df{critical volume} and the \\df{critical pressure}.   Show that every van der Waals gas has a critical temperature.   Compute the critical values \\(RT_c\\), \\(V_c\\), and \\(P_c\\) (in terms of the gas constants \\(a\\) and \\(b\\)).   Explain how you know that the point \\((V_c,P_c)\\) is a point of inflection.",

      "title": "Practice With Inverse Functions And Their Derivatives",
      "body": " Show that the natural logarithm is the only continuous function \\(f\\) defined on the interval \\((0,\\infty)\\) which satisfies    \\[ f(xy) \u003d f(x) + f(y) \\qquad \\text{for all \\(x,y \u003e 0\\)} \\] and    \\[ f(e) \u003d 1.   \\] \u003ci\u003eHint.\u003c/i\u003e Assume that you are given a function \\(f\\colon (0,\\infty) \\sto \\R\\) about which you know only three things:\n  (i) \\(f\\) is continuous;\n  (i) \\(f(xy) \u003d f(x) + f(y)\\) for all \\(x,y \u003e0\\); and\n  (i) \\(f(e) \u003d 1\\).   What you must prove is that    \\begin{equation}        f(x) \u003d \\ln x \\qquad \\text{for every \\(x \u003e 0\\).}    \\end{equation} The crucial result that you will need to prove is that    \\begin{equation}       f(u^r) \u003d r f(u)    \\end{equation} holds for every real number \\(u \u003e 0\\) and every rational number\\(r\\).   Once you have this, then you can use propositions\\ref{prop_rats_dense} and\\ref{prop_cont_prsrvs_seq_conv} to conclude that     \\[ f(e^y) \u003d y \\qquad \\text{for every real number\\(y\\)}.   \\] Then substituting \\(\\ln x\\) for \\(y\\) will give you the desired result\\eqref{ln01}.   Prove \\eqref{ln02} first for the case \\(r \u003d n\\) where \\(n\\) is a natural number.   Then prove it for the case \\(r \u003d 1/n\\) where \\(n\\) is a natural number.   Use these results to show that\\eqref{ln02} holds for every positive rational number.    Next deal with the case \\(r \u003d 0\\).    Finally verify \\eqref{ln02} for the case where \\(r\\) is a negative rational number.   (To do this prove that \\(f(1/v) \u003d -f(v)\\) for all \\(v \u003e 0\\) by substituting \\(v\\) for \\(x\\) and \\(1/v\\) for \\(y\\) in(ii).)",
      "allAnswers": [],
      "tags": "inverse functions, inverse functions and their derivatives, logarithmic functions, the natural logarithm, exponential functions, trigonometric and inverse trigonometric functions, implicit differentiation, word problem",

      "title": "A Upper And Lower Darboux Sums Question",
      "body": " Consider the function \\(f(x) \u003d x^2 + 1\\) defined on the closed interval \\([0,2]\\).    For each natural number \\(n\\) let \\(P_n \u003d (x_0, x_1, \\dots, x_n)\\) be a regular partition of the interval \\([0,2]\\) into \\(n\\) subintervals.    Denote the length of the \\(k^{\\text{th}}\\) subinterval by \\(\\Delta x_k\\).    (Thus for a regular partition \\(\\Delta x_1 \u003d \\Delta x_2 \u003d \\dots \u003d \\Delta x_n\\).) \\begin{definition} Let \\(P_n\\) be a regular partition of \\([0,2]\\) as above.    For each \\(k\\) between \\(1\\) and \\(n\\) let \\(a_k\\) be the point in the \\(k^{\\text{th}}\\) subinterval \\([x_{k-1},x_k]\\) where \\(f\\) has its smallest value and \\(b_k\\) be the point in \\([x_{k-1},x_k]\\) where \\(f\\) has its largest value.    Then let      \\[ L(n) \u003d \\sum_{k\u003d1}^n f(a_k)\\Delta x_k \\qquad \\text{and} \\qquad U(n) \u003d \\sum_{k\u003d1}^n f(b_k)\\Delta x_k.   \\] The number \\(L(n)\\) is the \\df{lower sum} associated with the partition \\(P\\) and \\(U(n)\\) is  \\index{lower sum}%  \\index{upper sum}% the \\df{upper sum} associated with\\(P\\).   \\end{definition}",
      "allAnswers": [],

(Note: ``arbitrary\u0027\u0027 means ``unspecified\u0027\u0027.)       "uuid": "a54bcb0e-48b8-4d0d-be86-8340bf944525",
      "contentType": "question",
      "creatorUserId": "",
      "createdAt": 1437403432957,
      "anonymous": true,
      "submitted": true,
      "viewable": true,
      "karma": 3,
      "title": "A Evaluation Of Definite Integrals Using Antiderivatives Question",
      "body": " Define functions \\(f\\), \\(g\\), and \\(h\\) as follows:  \\begin{align*} h(x) \u0026\u003d \\begin{cases} 1, \u0026\\text{for \\(0 \\le x \\le 2\\)}\\\\                              x, \u0026\\text{for \\(2 \u003c x \\le 4\\)}.                            \\end{cases}\\\\  \\intertext{\\vphantom{.}}                  g(x) \u0026\u003d \\int_x^{x^2} h(t) dt                           \\qquad \\text{for \\(0 \\le x \\le 2\\)} \\\\  \\intertext{\\vphantom{.}}                  f(x) \u0026\u003d \\int_0^x g(t) dt                           \\qquad \\text{for \\(0 \\le x \\le 2\\)}.    \\end{align*}",

    {
      "uuid": "8466e12f-c93d-4093-8a21-bf717d2bbd79",
      "contentType": "question",
      "creatorUserId": "",
      "createdAt": 1437403432958,
      "anonymous": true,
      "submitted": true,
      "viewable": true,
      "karma": 3,
      "title": "Differentiation Of Indefinite Integrals Problem",
      "body": " What is the moral of this problem?  That is, what do these examples suggest        about the process of integration in general? \\begin{proof}[\u003ci\u003eHints for solution\u003c/i\u003e] When working with the first function \\(h\\) it is possible to get the ``right answers\u0027\u0027 to questions (i)---(iii) but at the same time fail to give coherent reasons for the assertions made.    This part of the problem is meant to encourage paying attention to the precise definitions of some of the terms.   Indeed, the correct answers will vary from text to text.    Some texts, for instance, distinguish between functions that are \u003ci\u003eincreasing\u003c/i\u003e and those that are \u003ci\u003estrictly increasing\u003c/i\u003e.    Other texts replace these terms by \u003ci\u003enondecreasing\u003c/i\u003e and \u003ci\u003eincreasing\u003c/i\u003e, respectively.    Some texts define \u003ci\u003econcavity\u003c/i\u003e only for functions which are twice differentiable; others define it in terms of the first derivative; still others define it geometrically.   This first part of the problem also provides an opportunity to review a few basic facts: differentiability implies continuity; continuity can be characterized (or defined) in terms of limits; and so on.   Unraveling the properties of the second function\\(g\\) is rather harder.   Try not to be put off by the odd looking definition of \\(g\\).    The crucial insight here is that by carrying out the indicated integration it is possible to express \\(g\\), at least piecewise, as a polynomial.    From a polynomial expression it is a simple matter to extract the required information.   Impatience at this stage is not a reliable friend.    It is not a good idea to try to carry out the integration before you have thought through the problem and discovered the necessity of dividing the interval into two pieces.    It may be helpful to compute the values of \\(g\\) at \\(x\u003d1.0, 1.1, 1.2, \\dots ,1.9, 2.0\\).    Notice that about midway in these computations something odd happens.    What is the precise point \\(p\\) where things change? Eventually one sees that \\(g\\) too is expressible as one polynomial on \\([0,p]\\) and as another polynomial on\\((p ,2]\\).   Once \\(g\\) has been expressed piecewise by polynomials it is possible to proceed with questions (i)--(iii).    To determine whether \\(g\\) is continuous at \\(p\\),  compute the right- and left-hand limits of \\(g\\) there.   The question of the differentiability of \\(g\\) is subtle and deserves some serious thought.   It may be tempting to carry over the format of continuity argument to decide about the differentiability of\\(g\\) at\\(p\\).   Suppose we compute the right- and left-hand limits of the derivative of \\(g\\) at\\(p\\) and find that they are not equal.   Can we then conclude that \\(g\\) is not differentiable at\\(p\\)? At first one is inclined to say \u003ci\u003eno\u003c/i\u003e, that all we have shown is that the derivative of \\(g\\) is not continuous at\\(p\\), which does not address the issue of the \u003ci\u003eexistence\u003c/i\u003e of \\(g\u0027(p)\\).   Interestingly enough, it turns out that the only way in which a differentiable function \\(F\\) can fail to be continuously differentiable at a point \\(a\\) is for either the right- or left-hand limit of \\(F\u0027(x)\\) \u003ci\u003eto fail to exist\u003c/i\u003e at\\(a\\).   The crucial result, which is a bit hard to find in beginning calculus texts, is proposition\\ref{prop_cont_diff}.   Thus when we discover that a function \\(F\\) is differentiable at all points other than\\(a\\), and that the limits \\(\\lim_{x \\sto a^{\\!-}}F \u0027(x)\\) and \\(\\lim_{x \\sto a^{\\!+}}F \u0027(x)\\) both exist but fail to be equal, there is only one possible explanation: \\(F\\) fails to be differentiable at\\(a\\).   After finding a piecewise polynomial expression for \\(g\\), another difficulty arises in determining whether \\(g\\) is concave up.    It is easy to see that \\(g\\) is concave up on the intervals \\((0,p)\\) and\\((p ,2)\\).    But this isn\u0027t enough to establish the property for the entire interval\\((0,2)\\).    In fact, according to the definition of concavity given in many texts \\(g\\) is \u003ci\u003enot\u003c/i\u003e concave up.    Why?  Because, according to Finney and Thomas (see\\cite{FinneyT:1990}, page 237), for example, concavity is defined only for differentiable functions.    A function is concave up on an interval only if its derivative is increasing on the interval.    So if our function \\(g\\) fails to be differentiable at some point it can not be concave up.   On the other hand, under any reasonable geometric definition of concavity \\(g\\) certainly \u003ci\u003eis\u003c/i\u003e concave up on\\((0,2)\\)---although it is a bit hard to show.    The solution to this dilemma is straightforward: pick a definition and stick to it.   Analysis of the last function \\(f\\) proceeds pretty much as for\\(g\\).    One new wrinkle is the difficulty in determining where \\(f\\) is positive.    The point at which \\(f\\) changes sign is a root of a fifth degree polynomial.    An approximation based either on the \u003ci\u003eintermediate value theorem\u003c/i\u003e or \u003ci\u003eNewton\u0027s method\u003c/i\u003e goes smoothly.   As with \\(g\\), conclusions concerning the concavity of \\(f\\) may differ depending on the definitions used.   This time both a geometrical definition and one based on the first derivative lead to one conclusion while a definition based on the second derivative leads to another.   Finally, for part (c) does it make any sense to regard integration as a ``smoothing\u0027\u0027 operation?  In what way? \\ns \\end{proof}",
      "allAnswers": [],
      "tags": "the fundamental theorem of calculus, Fundamental theorem of Calculus, differentiation of indefinite integrals, evaluation of definite integrals using antiderivatives, word problem",

Let \\(\\exp \u003d \\ln^{-1}\\).    Then the domain of \\(\\exp\\) is all of\\(\\R\\) and its range is the interval\\((0,\\infty)\\).\n  (j) Prove that \\(D\\exp(x) \u003d \\exp(x)\\).\n  (k) Show that \\(\\exp\\) is strictly increasing and concave up.\n  (l) Prove that if \\(x,y \\in \\R\\), then \\(\\exp(x+y) \u003d \\exp x \\cdot \\exp y\\).\n  (m) For every \\(a \u003e 0\\) and \\(x \\in \\R\\) define \\(a^x :\u003d \\exp(x\\ln a)\\).    Prove that \\(e^x \u003d \\exp x\\) for every\\(x\\).\n  (n) Prove that if \\(a \u003e 0\\) and \\(x,y \\in \\R\\), then \\(a^{x+y} \u003d  a^x \\cdot a^y\\).",

      "title": "Area Under A Curve Question",
      "body": " You are considering the problem of calculating the surface area of a solid of revolution.    The curve \\(y \u003d f(x)\\) (for \\(a \\le x \\le b\\)) has been rotated about the \\(x\\)-axis.    You set up a partition \\((x_0,x_1,\\dots,x_n)\\) of \\([a,b]\\) and approximate the surface area of the resulting solid by connecting consecutive points \\(\\bigl(x_{k-1},f(x_{k-1})\\bigr)\\) and \\(\\bigl(x_k,f(x_k)\\bigr)\\) by a straight line segment, which, when rotated about the \\(x\\)-axis, produces a portion of a cone.    Taking the limit of these conical approximations you end up with the integral   \\[ \\int_a^b2\\pi f(x)\\sqrt{1 + \\bigl(f\u0027(x)\\bigr)^2} dx \\] which you claim represents the surface area of the solid.   Your friend Fred has chosen to make cylindrical approximations rather than conical ones and produces the integral   \\[ \\int_a^b2\\pi f(x) dx \\] which he claims represents the surface area.    So you and Fred argue.   He says your formula is too complicated.    You say his is too simple to work.    Unable to convince him, you look up the formula in a well known calculus text and find that the author agrees with you.    Fred is unimpressed; he says the author probably made the same mistake you did.    You find several more references to support your work.   Fred thinks they all probably copied from the person who made the original mistake.   Find a \u003ci\u003ecompletely convincing\u003c/i\u003e argument that even skeptical Fred will accept that his formula can\u0027t be correct and that yours is better.",

      "title": "On Moment Of A Plane Region About A Lines",
      "body": " Consider a cable of uniform linear density hanging between two smooth pegs (of negligible diameter) at the same height.   The two free ends of the cable hang straight down and are 12 feet in length.   Place the origin of the coordinate system at the point where the sag of the cable is greatest.   Between the two pegs the cable hangs in a curve \\(y \u003d f(x)\\) for \\(-M \\le x \\le M\\) (where \\(2M\\) is the distance between the pegs).   Let \\(\\theta(x)\\) be the angle the (tangent to the) cable makes with the horizontal at each \\(x\\) between \\(-M\\) and \\(M\\).   The value of \\(\\theta\\) just to the left of \\(M\\) is \\(\\pi/3\\).   What is the total length of the cable? How far does it sag? How far apart are the pegs? \u003ci\u003eHint.\u003c/i\u003e  Suppose the cable\u0027s linear density is \\(\\delta\\) pounds per foot.   Let \\(T(x)\\) be the tension in the cable at the point \\((x,f(x))\\).   Try the following steps.\n  (a) Start by considering the horizontal and vertical components of the forces acting on a small piece of cable lying between \\(x\\) and \\(x + \\Delta x\\).    Show that \\(T(x)\\cos(\\theta(x))\\) is a constant, say \\(K\\).\n  (b) Find an expression for the derivative of \\(T(x)\\sin(\\theta(x))\\).   (It should involve the derivative of the  arclength of \\(f\\).)\n  (c) Use the results of (a) and (b) to calculate the derivative of \\(\\tan(\\theta(x))\\).\n  (d) Express \\(K\\) in terms of \\(\\delta\\).\n  (e) Substitute this in the result of (c).\n  (f) Use (e) to calculate the length of that portion of the cable lying between the pegs.   Write down the total length of the cable.\n  (g) In (e) make the substitution \\(u \u003d \\tan(\\theta(x))\\).   Treat the derivative \\(\\dfrac{du}{dx}\\) as a fraction.   Move all terms containing \\(x\\) to one side of the equation and all terms containing \\(u\\) to the other.   Integrate both sides.    Solve for \\(u\\).   Then evaluate the constant of integration by examining the relationship between \\(u(-M)\\) and \\(u(M)\\).\n  (h) Since \\(u\\) is \\(\\dfrac{dy}{dx}\\) a second integration will produce a formula for \\(y\\) and a second constant of integration.   Evaluate this second constant by looking at what happens at the origin.\n  (i) Evaluate \\(M\\) by setting the integral representing the arclength of the function you found in (h) equal to the value you computed in (f).   Give the exact answer in terms of natural logarithms and a decimal approximation.\n  (j) Find the sag in the cable and the distance between the pegs.",

      "contentType": "question",

      "karma": 3,
      "title": "Practice With Area Under A Curve",
      "body": " Let \\(R\\) be a bounded region in the plane and \\(L\\) a line which does not pass through any interior point of\\(R\\).    For the purposes of this problem assume the following facts about \\(M_L(R)\\), the moment of \\(R\\) about\\(L\\), to be known.\n  (1) If \\(R\\) is a rectangular region, then \\(M_L(R)\\) is the product of the area of \\(R\\) and the distance between the center of \\(R\\) and\\(L\\).    (Of course, the \u003ci\u003ecenter\u003c/i\u003e of a rectangle is the point at which the diagonals intersect.)\n  (2) If \\(R\\) is divided into nonoverlapping subregions \\(R_1, \\dots ,R_n\\), then the moment of \\(R\\) about \\(L\\) is the sum of the moments of the subregions \\(R_k\\) about\\(L\\).    That is,       \\[ M_L(R) \u003d \\sum_{k\u003d1}^n M_L(R_k).   \\] Now suppose that \\(f\\) and \\(g\\) are continuous functions on the interval\\([a,b]\\) and that \\(0 \\le g(x) \\le f(x)\\) for \\(a \\le x \\le b\\).   Let \\(R\\) be the region between the curves \\(y \u003d f(x)\\) and \\(y \u003d g(x)\\) for \\(a \\le x \\le b\\).   Set up appropriate Riemann sums to approximate the moment \\(M_x(R)\\) of \\(R\\) about the \\(x\\)-axis and the moment \\(M_y(R)\\) of \\(R\\) about the \\(y\\)-axis.       "title": "A Scalars Question",
      "body": " Prove that if \\((a_1,a_2,\\dots)\\) is a sequence of real numbers such that the series \\smash[b]{\\(\\D\\sum_{k\u003d1}^\\infty{a_k}^2\\)} converges, then the series \\(\\D\\sum_{k\u003d1}^\\infty\\frac1k a_k\\) converges absolutely.   \\begin{proof}[\u003ci\u003eHint for proof\u003c/i\u003e] You may find the following steps helpful in organizing your solution.\n  (i) The key to this problem is \u003ci\u003eMonotonic Sequence Theorem\u003c/i\u003e (MST)---see\\ref{sequences_MST}.\n  (i) The hypothesis of the result we are trying to prove is that the series \\smash[b]{\\(\\D\\sum_{k\u003d1}^\\infty{a_k}^2\\)} converges.   What, exactly, does this mean?\n  (i) For each natural number \\(n\\) let \\smash[b]{\\(b_n \u003d \\D\\sum_{k\u003d1}^n{a_k}^2\\)}.   Rephrase (ii) in terms of the sequence\\((b_n)\\).\n  (i) Is the sequence \\((b_n)\\) increasing?\n  (v) What, then, does the MST say about the sequence\\((b_n)\\)?\n  (v) For each natural number \\(n\\) let \\(c_n \u003d \\D\\sum_{k\u003d1}^n\\frac1{k^2}\\).    What do we know about the sequence\\((c_n)\\)? (If in doubt consult the \u003ci\u003e\\(p\\)-test\u003c/i\u003e\\ref{convergence_ptest}).    What does the MST say about the sequence\\((c_n)\\)?\n  (v) The conclusion we are trying to prove is that the series \\smash[b]{\\(\\D\\sum_{k\u003d1}^\\infty\\frac1k a_k\\)} converges absolutely.   What does this mean?\n  (v) For each natural number \\(n\\) let \\smash[b]{\\(s_n \u003d \\D\\sum_{k\u003d1}^n\\frac1k \\abs{a_k}\\)}.    Rephrase (vii) in terms of the sequence\\((s_n)\\).\n  (i) Explain how for each \\(n\\) we may regard the number \\(s_n\\) as the dot product of two vectors in\\(\\R^n\\).\n  (x) Apply the \u003ci\u003eSchwarz inequality\u003c/i\u003e\\ref{thm_Schwarz} to the dot product in(ix).    Use (v) and (vi) to establish that the sequence \\((s_n)\\) is bounded above.\n  (x) Use the MST one last time---keeping in mind what you said in(viii).   \\end{proof}",

      "body": " This, like the preceding problem, is a steepest descent problem.    However, we now suppose (probably contrary to fact) that for some reason we are unable to solve explicitly the resulting differential equations.    Instead we invoke an approximation technique.    Let    \\[ \\phi(x) \u003d 13{x_1}^2 - 42x_1 + 13{x_2}^2 + 6x_2 + 10x_1x_2 + 9 \\] for all \\(\\vc x\\) in\\(\\R^2\\).    The goal is to approximate the path of steepest descent.    Start at an arbitrary point \\(\\vc x^0\\) in \\(\\R^2\\) and choose a number \\(h \u003e 0\\).    At \\(\\vc x^0\\) compute the gradient of \\(\\phi\\), take \\(\\vc u^0\\) to be the unit vector pointing in the direction of \\(-\\nabla\\phi(\\vc x^0)\\), and then move \\(h\\) units in the direction of \\(\\vc u^0\\) arriving at a point\\(\\vc x^1\\).   Repeat the procedure: find the unit vector \\(\\vc u^1\\) in the direction of \\(-\\nabla\\phi(\\vc x^1)\\), then from \\(\\vc x^1\\) move \\(h\\) units along \\(\\vc u^1\\) to a point\\(\\vc x^2\\).    Continue in this fashion.    In other words, \\(\\vc x^0 \\in \\R^2\\) and \\(h \u003e 0\\) are arbitrary, and for \\(n \\ge 0\\)     \\[ \\vc x^{n+1} \u003d \\vc x^n + h\\vc u^n \\] where \\(\\vc u^n \u003d -\\norm{\\nabla\\phi(\\vc x^n)}^{-1}\\nabla\\phi(\\vc x^n)\\) .",

      "body": " Here is a problem from a thermodynamics text:       {\\narrower\\narrower Show that if \\(f(x,y,z) \u003d 0\\), then            \\[\\left(\\pd xy\\right)_z \\left(\\pd yz\\right)_x \\left(\\pd zx\\right)_y \u003d -1 .   \\]          \\par} \\noindent Your old pal, Fred Dimm, is in trouble again.    He is taking a class in thermodynamics and is baffled by the statement of the problem.   Among other things he notices that there is a mysterious \\(f\\) in the hypothesis that does not appear in the conclusion.    He wonders, not unreasonably, how assuming something about \\(f\\) is going to help him prove something that makes no reference whatever to that quantity.    He is also convinced that the answer is wrong: he thinks that the product of the partial derivatives should be \\(+1\\).   He claims it should be just like the single variable case: the chain rule says \\(\\dfrac{dy}{dt} \u003d \\dfrac{dy}{dx}\\dfrac{dx}{dt}\\) because we can cancel the \\(dx\\)\u0027s.   Help Fred by explaining the exercise to him.    And comment on his ``correction\u0027\u0027 of the problem.   Unfortunately, once you have explained all this to him, he still can\u0027t do the problem.    So also show him how to solve it.   \u003ci\u003eHint.\u003c/i\u003e Let \\(w \u003d f(x,y,z)\\).       "title": "Question On Chain Rule \\vskip 20 Pt Differentiation Is About Approximating (a Suitable Translation Of) A Smooth Function By A Linear One",
      "body": " Regard thermodynamics as having 5 fundamental variables: \\(T\\) (temperature), \\(V\\) (volume), \\(U\\) (internal energy), \\(P\\) (pressure), and \\(S\\) (entropy).   Any two of these may be regarded as ``independent\u0027\u0027.   If we take \\(T\\) and \\(V\\) to be our independent variables, then two basic laws of thermodynamics may be stated as follows:  \\begin{align} T\\left(\\pd ST\\right)_V \u0026\u003d                  \\left(\\pd UT\\right)_V   \\tag{I} \\\\                     T\\left(\\pd SV\\right)_T \u0026\u003d                  \\left(\\pd UV\\right)_T + P  \\tag{II}  \\end{align} Using (I) and (II) derive the following ``Maxwell relations\u0027\u0027:  \\begin{align} \\left(\\pd PT\\right)_V \u0026\u003d                  \\left(\\pd SV\\right)_T   \\tag{III} \\\\                     \\left(\\pd TV\\right)_S \u0026\u003d                  -\\left(\\pd PS\\right)_V   \\tag{IV} \\\\                     \\left(\\pd TP\\right)_S  \u0026\u003d                  \\left(\\pd VS\\right)_P.      \\tag{V}  \\end{align} \u003ci\u003eHints:\u003c/i\u003e You may wish to develop some tools.    For example, you may be able to derive (and use) the following formulas.    (Keep in mind that ``formulas\u0027\u0027 are typically \u003ci\u003econclusions\u003c/i\u003e of theorems: and theorems have \u003ci\u003ehypotheses\u003c/i\u003e as well as conclusions.)  \\begin{align}   \\left(\\pd yt\\right)_z            \\left(\\pd tx\\right)_z  \u0026\u003d            \\left(\\pd yx\\right)_z  \\tag{A}   \\\\            \\left(\\pd yx\\right)_z  \u0026\u003d            \\dfrac1{\\left(\\pd xy\\right)_z}  \\tag{B}  \\\\            \\left(\\pd yx\\right)_z  \u0026\u003d            - \\dfrac{\\left(\\pd zx\\right)_y}            {\\left(\\pd zy\\right)_x}   \\tag{C}  \\end{align} Once you have succeeded in deriving (A)--(C), you may choose to proceed as follows.    For (III) differentiate (I) with respect to \\(V\\) and (II) with respect to\\(T\\).    For (IV) use (C) to write the left side of (IV) in terms of the variables \\(T\\) and\\(V\\); use (A) to write the left side of (III) as a product of two terms one of which is \\(\\left(\\pd PS\\right)_V\\) then apply(III).   For (V) write \\(\\left(\\pd PT\\right)_S\\) as a product of two terms one of which is \\(\\left(\\pd PV\\right)_S\\), using(A).   Apply (C) to both terms of the product.   In the denominator of the resulting expression there will be a term with subscript \\(V\\); apply (B) to it.   Use (A) once more, and then (III).",

      "uuid": "a724c9c2-4106-466d-b383-5a029164d0b9",

      "createdAt": 1437403433115,
      "anonymous": true,

      "viewable": true,
      "karma": 3,
      "title": "Practice With Lagrange Multipliers",
      "body": " Following are three plausible conjectures.    In each case if the conjecture is true, prove it; and if it is false, give an example to show that it can fail.   (In the latter case, don\u0027t forget to \u003ci\u003eprove\u003c/i\u003e that your example really does what you claim.) \\noindent\\textbf{Conjecture 1.} If on every parametrized ray from the origin a function \\(f\\) of two variables is locally increasing at the origin, then \\(f\\) has a local minimum at the origin.   \\noindent\\textbf{Conjecture 2.} If a function \\(f\\) of two variables has a saddle point at the origin, then there are at least two separating pairs of rays from the origin such that \\(f\\) is locally increasing at the origin on one pair and locally decreasing at the origin on the other.   \\noindent\\textbf{Conjecture 3.}\\hphantom0  It is possible to find a function \\(f\\) of two variables for which there exist two separating triples of rays from the origin such that on one of the triples \\(f\\) is locally increasing at the origin and on the other \\(f\\) is locally decreasing at the origin.   \u003ci\u003eHint.\u003c/i\u003e A careful analysis of the behavior of the following surfaces may provide some insight into a couple of the conjectures.    \\begin{align*}           f(x,y) \u0026\u003d x^3 - 3xy^2, \\\\           g(x,y) \u0026\u003d y^2 -3x^2y + 2x^4.    \\end{align*}",
      "allAnswers": [],
      "tags": "more applications of the derivative, optimization of functions of several variables, global extrema, local extrema, saddle points, Lagrange multipliers, word problem",
      "url": "/question/a724c9c2-4106-466d-b383-5a029164d0b9",
      "source": "Exercises and Problems In Calculus (J. M. Erdman)",
      "topicUrl": "Calculus/Applications of the Derivative"

      "title": "Practice In Acceleration And Curvature",
      "body": " A parametrized curve \\(\\vc r\\) in \\(\\R^3\\) is a  \\index{unit!speed curve}%  \\index{curve!unit speed}% \\df{unit speed curve} if its speed \\(\\norm{\\vc v(t)}\\) is \\(1\\) for each\\(t\\).    Recall that the length of arc between the points \\(\\vc r(0)\\) and \\(\\vc r(t)\\) on such a curve is \\(s \u003d \\int_0^t\\norm{\\vc v(\\tau)} d\\tau \u003d t\\); thus we may say that a unit speed curve has been  \\index{parametrization!by arclength}%  \\index{arclength!parametrization by}% \\df{parametrized by arclength}.   In this problem we wish to attach a moving orthonormal frame of coordinates to a curve in such a way that one of the axes always points in the direction of the unit tangent vector \\(\\vc T\\) and a second axis points in the direction of the unit normal\\(\\vc N\\).   (The third axis is called \\(\\vc B\\), for  \\index{binormal}%  \\index{B@\\(B\\) (unit binormal vector)}% \u003ci\u003eunit binormal\u003c/i\u003e.)   When a geometric curve (as opposed to a parametrized one) has been parametrized by arclength (or when a parametrized curve has been reparametrized by arclength), the business of deriving properties of the moving \\(\\vc T - \\vc N - \\vc B\\) frame is fairly straightforward.    That is the task here.    The idea is to write up a coherent introduction to moving frames.    Include the material in items (a)--(i) below,  but do \u003ci\u003enot\u003c/i\u003e break up your exposition into chunks called (a), (b), (c), \u003ci\u003eetc.\u003c/i\u003e",

    {
      "uuid": "f2f03aa6-ad12-4ecd-8e60-bf78c0631a0b",
      "contentType": "question",
      "creatorUserId": "",
      "createdAt": 1437403433156,
      "anonymous": true,
      "submitted": true,
      "viewable": true,
      "karma": 3,
      "title": "A Surfaces Of Revolution Question",
      "body": " You are considering the problem of calculating the surface area of a solid of revolution.    The curve \\(y \u003d f(x)\\) (for \\(a \\le x \\le b\\)) has been rotated about the \\(x\\)-axis.    You set up a partition \\((x_0,x_1,\\dots,x_n)\\) of \\([a,b]\\) and approximate the surface area of the resulting solid by connecting consecutive points \\(\\bigl(x_{k-1},f(x_{k-1})\\bigr)\\) and \\(\\bigl(x_k,f(x_k)\\bigr)\\) by a straight line segment, which, when rotated about the \\(x\\)-axis, produces a portion of a cone.    Taking the limit of these conical approximations you end up with the integral     \\[ 2\\pi\\int_a^b f(x)\\sqrt{1 + \\bigl(f\u0027(x)\\bigr)^2} dx \\] which you claim represents the surface area of the solid.   Your friend Fred has chosen to make cylindrical approximations rather than conical ones and produces the integral     \\[ 2\\pi\\int_a^b f(x) dx \\] which he claims represents the surface area.    So you and Fred argue.   He says your formula is too complicated to compute.    You say his is too simple to work.    Unable to convince him, you look up the formula in a well known calculus text and find that the author agrees with you.   Fred is unimpressed; he says the author probably made the same mistake you did.    You find several more references to support your work.   Fred thinks they all probably copied from the person who made the original mistake.   Find a \u003ci\u003ecompletely convincing\u003c/i\u003e argument that even skeptical Fred will accept that his formula can\u0027t be correct and that yours is better.",
      "allAnswers": [],
      "tags": "surface area, surfaces of revolution, surface area, word problem",
      "url": "/question/f2f03aa6-ad12-4ecd-8e60-bf78c0631a0b",
      "source": "Exercises and Problems In Calculus (J. M. Erdman)",

    {
      "uuid": "5d83c7ae-27cb-4996-ac5e-ac8a0842cf10",
      "contentType": "question",
      "creatorUserId": "",
      "createdAt": 1437403433156,
      "anonymous": true,
      "submitted": true,
      "viewable": true,
      "karma": 3,
      "title": "Surface Area",
      "body": " In many calculus texts the authors derive the formula for the arc length of a smooth curve by taking the limit of sums of lengths of polygonal paths inscribed in the curve.    The purpose of this problem is to inquire into the possibility of doing the ``same thing\u0027\u0027 to find the surface area of a smooth surface.    In particular, consider a (vertical) right circular cylinder with height \\(h\\) and base radius\\(r\\).   Partition the surface of this cylinder by \\(m+1\\) equally spaced horizontal circles, thus creating \\(m\\) sub-cylinders of height\\(h/m\\) (and radius\\(r\\)).    Then partition each circle into \\(n\\) circular arcs by means of \\(n\\) equally spaced points.    (The points on one circle need not necessarily be directly above those on the circle below.) Now approximate the surface area of each sub-cylinder by the area of triangles inscribed in the sub-cylinder using these points as vertices.    In each sub-cylinder there will be \\(2n\\) such triangles---\\(n\\) having two vertices on the upper circle and \\(n\\) having two vertices on the lower circle.   Thus, altogether, there will be \\(2mn\\) triangles the sum of whose areas approximates the surface area of the original cylinder.   Now, of course, the question is: what can we say about the limit of the sum of the areas of these triangles as \\(m\\) and \\(n\\) get large?  Does it give us the correct expression for the area of a cylinder?  (How, incidentally, can we be sure what the surface area of a right circular cylinder really \u003ci\u003eought\u003c/i\u003e to be?)  Thinking about the problem in more precise terms, we need to ask whether this double limit even exists.    If not, can we make the corresponding iterated limits exist by restricting \\(m\\) and \\(n\\) in some way?  Does the answer depend on the relative rates of growth of \\(m\\) and\\(n\\)?  What happens if we require \\(m\\) and \\(n\\) to be in some fixed ratio?  That is, will the limit depend on the shape of the triangles? After considering these matters, what do you think of the prospects of generalizing the derivation of the formula for arc length to one for surface area?",
      "allAnswers": [],
      "tags": "surface area, surfaces of revolution, surface area, word problem",
      "url": "/question/5d83c7ae-27cb-4996-ac5e-ac8a0842cf10",
      "source": "Exercises and Problems In Calculus (J. M. Erdman)",
      "topicUrl": "Calculus/Multiple Integrals/Surface Area"
